title: Last Stand at Azovstal: Inside the Siege That Shaped the Ukraine War
abstract: For 80 days, at a sprawling steelworks, a relentless Russian assault met unyielding Ukrainian resistance. This is how it was for those who fought, and for those trapped beneath the battlefield.

multimedia.caption: By May, after months of battle, the Azovstal Iron and Steel Works was a charred skeleton.
By May, after months of battle, the Azovstal Iron and Steel Works was a charred skeleton.
By May, after months of battle, the Azovstal Iron and Steel Works was a charred skeleton.

title: Pope to Offer a Long-Sought Apology to Canada’s Indigenous People
abstract: Pope Francis will travel to an Indigenous community in Canada to apologize for the church’s role in residential schools that tried to erase Indigenous culture, and where thousands of children died.
byline: By Ian Austen and Elisabetta Povoledo

multimedia.caption: A line of children’s clothing set along a highway in British Columbia last year represented the children who died at the Kamloops Indian Residential School.
multimedia.copyright: Amber Bracken for The New York Times

title: Below an Israeli City, a Musical Harmony Belies the Tensions Above Ground
abstract: In an underground reservoir built 1,233 years ago in a city that saw sectarian riots last year, visitors hear a beguiling musical composition that combines Arab love songs with Hebrew poetry.

multimedia.caption: Visitors at the Pool of the Arches, a subterranean reservoir beneath Ramla, a city in Israel with a mixed population of Arabs and Jews.
multimedia.copyright: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

title: In Japan, Abe Suspect’s Grudge Against Unification Church Is a Familiar One
abstract: The man accused of killing Shinzo Abe said his mother’s huge donations to the church bankrupted his family. Many others in Japan have similar stories.
byline: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno

multimedia.caption: Tomihiro Tanaka, president of the Japanese branch of the Unification Church, during a moment of silence for former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe at a Tokyo news conference last week.

title: Conductor Dies After Collapsing During Performance in Munich
abstract: Stefan Soltesz was in the middle of Richard Strauss’s “The Silent Woman” when he fell from his podium shortly before the end of the first act.

multimedia.caption: Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.
Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.

title: Russia Strikes Odesa Port, Stirring Doubts on Deal to Export Grain
abstract: The string of explosions in Ukraine’s most important port came less than 24 hours after the two countries struck a deal on grain shipments, and prompted accusations from Ukrainian leaders that Russia could not be trusted.
byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Erika Solomon

multimedia.caption: A grain terminal at the port of Odesa on Saturday, after a string of explosions hit the city. Before the war, billions of dollars worth of grain was exported every year from the port to countries around the world.

title: Amid Sri Lanka’s Crisis, Cricket Carries On
abstract: The success of the men’s national team has offered solace to the country, and one fan called the players “brand ambassadors during this time of hardship.”

multimedia.caption: Antigovernment protesters atop a 17th- century fort overlooking the cricket stadium in Galle, Sri Lanka, while the home team played Australia in June.

title: The Ephemeral Art of Mexico City’s Food Stalls
abstract: In the heart of Mexico's capital, the colorful signs that have come to define the urban landscape of the city are being erased.
byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Jordi Ruiz Cirera

title: Draghi’s Fall Reverberates Beyond Italy
abstract: The downfall of Italy’s prime minister has raised concerns across Europe about the power of populist movements and whether they will erode unity against Russian aggression.

title: Mossad Sheds New Light on Argentina Terrorist Attacks in 1990s
abstract: An investigation by the Israeli spy agency found that Hezbollah had set up a cell to conduct the attacks and rejected suspicions that Argentines or Iranian officials in Buenos Aires had been involved.

multimedia.caption: A billboard in Buenos Aires with the names of victims of a July 1994 bombing of a Jewish community center in the city. The sign at the top reads, “Remembering the endless pain.”

title: After Mocking France’s Literary Elite, a Fraught Invite Into the Club
abstract: Mohamed Mbougar Sarr, a Senegal-born writer, has won high praise and top prizes from Paris’s insular publishing establishment. But the novelist wonders: Is it an endorsement or “a way to silence me”?

multimedia.caption: Last year Mohamed Mbougar Sarr won France’s top literary prize, the Goncourt, established in 1903.

title: The Race to Succeed Boris Johnson, Explained
abstract: A former top finance official, Rishi Sunak, and the foreign secretary, Liz Truss, are competing to replace Britain’s departing prime minister. Here’s a guide to the contest.

title: Deep in a Covid Wave, Europe Counts Cases and Carries On
abstract: Even in countries that once took strict measures, the authorities are relying on vaccination and past infections to take the sting out of Omicron subvariants.

title: Pakistan’s Deadly Flood Season Worsened by Climate Change and Bad Infrastructure
abstract: Monsoon rains have devastated Pakistan’s economic hub, Karachi, adding urgency to pleas to better equip cities to handle more frequent extreme weather.
byline: By Zia ur-Rehman, Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood

title: A French University Confronts Medical Crimes and Its Nazi Past
abstract: A report on the University of Strasbourg’s takeover by Nazis during World War II and on medical crimes they committed there sheds light on a period that had been mostly scrubbed from official memory.

multimedia.caption: At the University of Strasbourg’s anatomy building, a small brass plaque is the only public memorial to 86 Jews murdered so that a Nazi scientist could collect their skeletons.

title: ‘An abyss of fear’: A report accuses Russia of further abuses against civilians.
abstract: Human Rights Watch cataloged a litany of torture, inhumane treatment, arbitrary detention and disappearances in southern Ukraine and said that the atrocities could amount to war crimes.

title: Fears rise for a rights activist captured while fighting for Ukraine.

title: ‘Parentese’ Is Truly a Lingua Franca, Global Study Finds
abstract: In an ambitious cross-cultural study, researchers found that adults around the world speak and sing to babies in similar ways.

multimedia.caption: As part of the study, 50,000 people from 187 countries and representing 199 languages were asked to determine whether a song or a passage of speech was being addressed to a baby or an adult.

title: Turkey’s Leader Remains a Headache for Biden Despite Aiding in Ukraine Deal
